 BOSTON: he said.  

   A judge committed Weston to the Warm Springs hospital for 53
days in 1996, apparently after Weston made a threat against
President Clinton and was interviewed by the Secret Service.

   After being placed on medication, he was released on Dec. 2,
1996, because the hospital ``deemed him no longer a threat to
himself or others,'' according to a spokesman for Gov. Marc
Racicot. A hospital employee drove him to his cabin in nearby
Rimini, the spokesman said, and made arrangements for him to
receive further treatment at a mental health center in Waterloo,
Ill., near his parents' rural home outside Valmeyer in southern
Illinois.

   Alcorn described this as ``Greyhound therapy,'' a way to save
Montana money by buying Weston a one-way bus ticket for a trip out
of the state.

   In a series of interviews on Sunday, Weston's parents and
sister, April Callahan, said that he returned to Illinois with
three medications (whose names they did not remember) and that he
stopped taking them about a week later, despite his family's
protests. While his family described their growing concern over his
paranoid delusions, they also seemed to understand little about how
to seek help for him, or what treatment was available.

   The only community mental health clinic in Waterloo is Human
Support Services, a state-funded center. A spokesman for the
clinic, Rob Singer, refused to say on Monday whether Weston had
been a client there after his return from Montana.

   Torrey said people like Weston would be less likely to fall
through the cracks if states like Montana and Illionois used
existing laws that provide for involuntary outpatient treatment.
Such laws allow states to force a patient to take his medication if
he fails to show up for appointments at a local clinic or stops
taking his medication.

   Preventing a shooting like that attributed to Weston is
particularly difficult because the relationship between mental
illness and violence is very sensitive, and many experts have been
cautious about publicizing new research suggesting that in certain
situations the emotionally disturbed are more violent than other
people.

   Such situations occur when mentally ill persons have strong
paranoid symptoms that someone is out to get them or hear a voice
telling them to kill, said Bruce Link, a professor at Columbia
University School of Public Health. Another is when a patient fails
to show up for treatment or is off his medication, said Jeffrey
Sawnson, an assistant professor of psychiatry at Duke University.

   Last May, a MacArthur Foundation study found that mental
patients are no more violent than others unless they are abusing
drugs or alcohol. And Swanson said it is important to remember that
the mentally ill are responsible for only about 4 percent of
overall violence, making mental illness a smaller risk factor for
violence than being young, male or poor. But in a sign of how the
experts disagree on the subject, Torrey stressed that mentally ill
people commit 1,000 homicides a year.
